So I had my interview today. All was going reasonably well until she slowly pulled out a piece of paper and a calculator. She told me to follow her into her lab (she gave me a mini tour of it) and then she sat me down to take a quiz of some sorts. She kept saying that "it's not a test, I just want to see what you remember." So I sat down to TRY to take it (note the emphasis on the word try!) I was so mortified 30 minutes later when I went to hand it in (the first words out of my mouth were "I feel so silly...," because I had a really hard time on her "not test." It consisted of about 15 questions that involved dilutions, conversions, and other mathematical computations that you are supposed to learn in Freshman Biology or Chemistry. She told me not to worry too much about it though. I'm not giving up hope yet. She was reading a paper I wrote for some research I did my last semester in school and she seemed really impressed. If I get the job I'd be in charge of the student workers, keeping up the lab (like ordering supplies) and I'd also be doing some sort of research project on my own too. The starting off salary is about $18,500 per year for people without experience (way more than Book A salary so I'll be happy) Lets just hope that she was being totally serious when she said that most people can't remember how to do those kinds of calculations the first time.... Keep your fingers and toes crossed for me guys!

On Sunday, July 25, 2004, Lance Armstrong became the first person to win six Tours de France. As the peloton (the group of cyclists) was making its way to the Champs-Elysees in Paris, the officals handed champagne to Lance and the other members of the U.S. Postal team. Then the peloton let them ride nine abreast in the front. Along side them, in an open field, was a group of Americans in a World War II era jeep, waving American flags and cheering. Honnestly, it made me cry to see it. Everyone on the Tour, regardless of their team or nationality, was overcome with emotion to witness and be a part of this historical moment. One of the first things I'm going to do once I'm back in the States is buy a racing bike. I've promised myself to get in shape and ride my bike across parts of the country. Wouldn't it be fun to see the U.S. on a bike????

There's a huge walled city/castle up on a hill that dates back hundreds and hundreds of years. (It's ten times bigger than a Medieval Times restaurant, one hundred times cooler and it's real!) When I wasn't sight-seeing I was hanging out in this one bar with the other Tour de France fans. I met some New Zealanders and some Scottish folks. Then on Sunday I got up very early and staked out my spot on the side of the road to see the Tour. At around 12:50 all kinds of offical cars came zooming past me and then just a few seconds later the riders crested the hill and whizzed past me in an instant. It was so awesome! I saw my favorite French team, Brioches La BoulangÃ¨re, and the current Maillot Jaune--"yellow jersey"--Thomas Voeckler. I cheered him on and he smiled back at me. All in all it was great but, of course, it only lasted about three seconds. So I watched the rest of the race on TV with the old French guys in their usual bar. Some old dude who must have been drinking since earlier that morning came over and asked me something incomprehensible and I just muttered back "je ne comprends pas." And when he asked me if I didn't understand French I told him that I spoke French very well but that I didn't understand his drunk ass--but politely, of course. Internship update: only four weeks left before I go to Ireland and finish this damned thing. I should be back in Baton Rouge and in my black apron by early October. Get that Southern hospitality coming...Oh, and some Southern Pecan Decaf would be nice too... LeCastor
